conversation.text: You need 1 cup of rice for the pan.
What kind of rice do I need to use?
Type of rice does not matter, once you add herbs and spices, those will incorporate to the flavor
evidence: Put 1 cup (175-185 grams) of rice into a pan
Put 1 cup (175-185 grams) of rice into a pan
Put 1 cup (175-185 grams) of rice into a pan
Your choice of herbs and spices will depend on the specific flavor profile or ethnic cuisine you're interested in making.

conversation.text: Thank you. What is next?
Use 1 tablespoon of oil (type also does not matter, however, it is better ot use fattier oils like sesame or coconut to add to the flavor).
evidence: pour enough cooking oil or butter in to evenly coat it, usually 1 tablespoon
Avoid grapeseed and canola oil. Instead, use fattier oils like sesame oil, coconut oil, or olive oil to get more flavor.

conversation.text: What should the rice look like when toasting?
It will start to get a brown color and have a nutty aroma.
evidence: You'll know it's starting to toast once you smell a nutty aroma.

conversation.text: Okay, it looks light brown is that correct?
Yes, the is correct!
Okay, what is the next step?
Next mix in your herbs and spices (usually in amounts between 1/4 teaspoon and 1 teaspoon, depending on what you like). As said earlier, this will add the flavor.
evidence: Mix in the herbs and spices of your choice.
Your choice of herbs and spices will depend on the specific flavor profile or ethnic cuisine you're interested in making.
amounts between ¼ teaspoon (1 gram) and 1 teaspoon (4 grams) depending on your tastes.

conversation.text: Does it matter what types of spices? I like garlic personally.
No, whatever suits you! Garlic and shallots will give lots of flavor, but oregano, parsley, turmeric all still go well with rice!
evidence: a single shallot, a clove of garlic, or 1 tablespoon (14 grams) of chopped ginger) will give your rice tons of flavor.
Seasonings like oregano, pepper, parsley and turmeric go well with brown rice,

conversation.text: Awesome, I used garlic, shallots, oregano, and parsley.
Would you like to know the next step?
Yes, I would like to know the next step
Boil 2.5 cups of water separately in a pot, once it boils, add to rice.
evidence: While your rice is toasting, boil water separately in a pot or kettle.

conversation.text: Do I add to rice while it is still toasting?
Yes! pour over the seasoned rice.
evidence: When it has reached a boil, pour it over your seasoned rice in the pan.

conversation.text: Awesome, that is complete. What is next?
Stir the rice, cover, and let sit for 20 minutes. I suggest setting a timer.
evidence: Cook the mixture on low for 20 minutes.

conversation.text: Timer just went off! What do I do?
Let the ride stay in the pot covered for 5 minutes. Then fluff with a fork.
evidence: Once the rice is cooked, let it stand for 5 minutes, then uncover it and fluff it with a fork.

conversation.text: Alright! Am I done?
Yes! Great job and enjoy the rice!
I will! Thank you for the help!

procedure.summary: Combine your rice  with cooking oil or melted butter in a pan.
procedure.description: Put 1 cup (175-185 grams) of rice into a pan and pour enough cooking oil or butter in to evenly coat it, usually 1 tablespoon (15 mL). Toast the rice in the oil over medium heat. You'll know it's starting to toast once you smell a nutty aroma. Avoid grapeseed and canola oil. Instead, use fattier oils like sesame oil, coconut oil, or olive oil to get more flavor.

procedure.summary: Mix in the herbs and spices of your choice.
procedure.description: Your choice of herbs and spices will depend on the specific flavor profile or ethnic cuisine you're interested in making. Regardless of what seasonings you choose, sprinkle them over your toasting rice a little bit at a time until they are at the strength you like based on your own tastes. Seasonings like oregano, pepper, parsley and turmeric go well with brown rice, usually in amounts between ¼ teaspoon (1 gram) and 1 teaspoon (4 grams) depending on your tastes. Adding aromatic seasonings in small amounts (a single shallot, a clove of garlic, or 1 tablespoon (14 grams) of chopped ginger) will give your rice tons of flavor.

procedure.summary: Add 2.5 cups (590 mL) of boiling water to the pan.
procedure.description: While your rice is toasting, boil water separately in a pot or kettle. When it has reached a boil, pour it over your seasoned rice in the pan.

After adding the boiling water, stir the contents of your pan and then cover it with a lid. Cook the mixture on low for 20 minutes. Once the rice is cooked, let it stand for 5 minutes, then uncover it and fluff it with a fork.
